p.text: Supreme Court Act No 52 of 1970, assent 14 October 1970, commenced 1 July 1972, as amended by:

p.text: An Act to provide for the concurrent administration of law and equity in the Supreme Court; to amend and consolidate the law with respect to the administration of justice and the procedure and practice of the Supreme Court; to repeal the Common Law Procedure Act 1899 , the Equity Act 1901 , and certain other Acts; to amend the Partnership Act 1892 , and certain other Acts; and for purposes connected therewith.
This Act may be cited as the Supreme Court Act 1970.
Except as provided in subsection (2) , this Act shall commence on a day to be appointed by the Governor and notified by proclamation published in the Gazette.
Part 9 of this Act shall commence on the date upon which the assent of Her Majesty to this Act is signified.
The Act was assented to 14 October 1970 and commenced 1 July 1972.
Subject to this and any other Act, the Crown is bound by, and has the benefit of, this Act and the rules.
In subsection (1) , Crown includes not only the Crown in right of New South Wales but also the Crown in all its other capacities.
[s 4 rep Act 28 of 1985 s 3 and Sch 1(1)]
Each Act mentioned in the First Schedule to this Act is, to the extent therein expressed, hereby repealed.

Any Act in force immediately before the commencement of this Act which is inconsistent with the rules shall be superseded to the extent of such inconsistency and while such inconsistency continues to exist.

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 6.5] Effect of the rules made under the Supreme Court Act

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 6.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 124(3), s 19.

heading.title: Effect of the rules made under the Supreme Court Act

p.text: In s 19(1) of the Supreme Court Act “the rules” are defined to mean “the Rules of the Court from time to time in force” and include rules made by the Rules Committee (see s 19 ). This means that a rule made by the Rules Committee can override any inconsistent procedural provisions in Acts formerly in force. While this is unusual there does not seem to be any objection in principle to this way of overriding legislation: See Pearce on Delegated Legislation (1977). See also paras 1–17 of the NSW Law Reform Commission's Report No 14 (1971) as to the reasons for this section. A further provision for the amendment of statutory provisions is contained in s 124(3) (as inserted by the Courts Legislation Further Amendment Act 1998). That section permits certain rules to have effect despite any Act, and is not limited to Acts that were formerly in force.

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 6.10] Priority of the Uniform Civil Procedure Rules

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 6.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Pt 83, r 1.7, Sch 2.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 11.

heading.title: Priority of the Uniform Civil Procedure Rules

p.text: The Uniform Civil Procedure Rules (UCPR) prevail over any provision of the rules made under the Supreme Court Act, to the extent of any inconsistency and subject to any express contrary provision contained in r 1.7 and Sch 2 of the UCPR: see s 11 of the CPA 2005. The contrary provisions contained in Sch 2 relate to Pt 83 (Admiralty List) and the Supreme Court (Corporations) Rules 1999.
[s 7 rep Act 85 of 1999 s 4 and Sch 4]
In any Act, rule of court or regulation in force immediately before the commencement of this Act:
a reference to the Court in Banco or to the Full Court or to the Court as a court consisting of two or more Judges shall be construed as a reference to the Court of Appeal,

a reference to the Court or to a Judge in any of the jurisdictions specified in the First Column of the Table below or to the practice or procedure of the Court in any of those jurisdictions shall be construed as a reference to the Division specified opposite that jurisdiction in the Second Column of that Table or, as the case may be, to the practice or procedure in that Division:
a reference to the Judge exercising the matrimonial causes jurisdiction of the Court or appointed to exercise that jurisdiction shall be construed as a reference to the Chief Judge in Divorce,

a reference to a writ, whether of prohibition, mandamus, or certiorari or of any other description by which the Court formerly had jurisdiction to grant any relief or remedy shall, subject to subsection two of this section, be construed as a reference to the judgment or order by which the Court may grant that relief or remedy under this Act and the rules,

a reference to the Master in Equity or to the Master in the protective jurisdiction of the Court shall, subject to the rules, be construed as a reference to the master assigned to the Equity Division or, as the case may be, to the master assigned to the Protective Division or, where two or more masters are so assigned, to the senior master so assigned,

a reference to the holder of an office named in the First Column of the Table below shall, subject to the rules, be construed as a reference to the holder of the office named in the Second Column of that Table opposite to the name of the firstmentioned office:

row.entry: Deputy Master and Registrar in Equity
Registrar of the Court of Appeal
Registrar of the Court of Appeal

p.text: a reference to the verdict or finding of a jury in any proceedings or on any issue in any proceedings on a trial with a jury shall, unless the context or subject matter otherwise indicates or requires, extend, in the case of proceedings on a common law claim tried without a jury pursuant to this Act, to the determination of the Court in the proceedings or on any such issue on a trial without a jury, and
a reference to an action of ejectment in the Court shall be construed as a reference to proceedings in the Court for possession of land.
[subs (1) am Act 41 of 1972 s 3]
Paragraph (d) of subsection (1) does not apply to a reference to:
the writ of habeas corpus ad subjiciendum,
any writ of execution for the enforcement of a judgment or order of the Court, or
any writ in aid of any such writ of execution.
Legislation cited in [SCA s 8.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 [SCA s 38].

The Supreme Court Act was amended in 1998 to reduce the number of divisions of the court. As a result of that amendment there are only two divisions: the Equity Division and the Common Law Division: see [SCA s 38] .
A repeal made by section 5 or an amendment made by section 7 shall not revive anything not in force or existing immediately before the commencement of this Act.
